description.plain:
DeAndre Cortez Way (b. July 28, 1990), better known as his stage name Soulja Boy, is a rapper, producer, and social media influencer born in Chicago, Illinois and raised in Atlanta, Georgia whose debut single “Crank That (Soulja Boy)” hit No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100 and would hold that spot for seven non-consecutive weeks.

At 15 years old, Soulja  began uploading songs to SoundClick and eventually moved to YouTube and MySpace. By March 2007, he came up with the concept behind “Crank That” and uploaded the song—and a video of its accompanying dance—online. Two months later, in May 2007, “Crank That” started to go viral. He signed to Interscope Records in the same month. By October, his major label debut album Souljaboytellem.com was released and peaked at No. 4 on the Billboard 200. But critics quickly blasted his simplistic lyrics and unorthodox flows, questioning whether or not he’d just be a one-hit wonder.

“Crank That” earned him a Grammy nomination and he would continue to find success with the songs “Kiss Me Thru the Phone”, “Turn My Swag On”, and “Pretty Boy Swag”. He’s released mixtape after mixtape, left Interscope, made noise with rumors of signing with YMCMB and eventually launched own label Stacks on Deck Entertainment.

In 2016, Soulja Boy announced that he signed a $400 million deal with World Poker Fund Holdings.

description.plain:
One of the most notorious songs of all time, “Crank That (Soulja Boy)” is the debut and breakout single for Chicago rapper and television personality Soulja Boy Tell ‘Em, better known simply as Soulja Boy.

Serving as the first single from Soulja Boy’s 2007 debut album Souljaboytellem.com, the song quickly blew up and hit the number one spot on the Billboard Hot 100 chart on September 14, 2007, where it stayed for seven weeks. “Crank That” went on to become one of the biggest hits from the snap genre and is still remembered as one of the most prominent dance songs of the 2000’s to this day.

Much of the song’s popularity is due to the dance that accompanies it, demonstrated in the music video by Soulja Boy and others. The dance was explained by Wall Street Journal upon the song’s release:

Dancers bounce back on their heels, ripple their hands, crank their wrists like motorcyclists, then lunge into a Superman pose.

description.plain: One of many historical pieces of musical writing by Soulja Boy. In this particular masterpiece, Soulja Boy describes his lust for a certain female, whom he cannot be with at this moment, so he calls her to ‘kiss him thru the phone’. Soulja Boy employs various literary techniques and uses extreme amounts of lyrical flair to get his point across.

songs.title: Beef (Quavo Diss)

description.plain:
After beefing with Shia LaBoeuf, Soulja Boy started making threats to Migos member Quavo.

The beef allegedly started when Soulja Boy reached out to Quavo, but Quavo didn’t want to associate himself with Soulja because of all the dumb stuff he recently did and all the beefs he started and ended.  Ironically, Soulja said he was cool with Takeoff and Offset, but has problems with Quavo.

songs.full_title: Zan With That Lean by Soulja Boy (Ft. Kwony Cash)
songs.title: Zan With That Lean
songs.title_with_featured: Zan With That Lean (Ft. Kwony Cash)

description.plain: Young star gets rich, grows up, and takes drugs: It’s a showbiz story about as old as time, and in rap music right now, seemingly no young star is taking as many drugs as Soulja Boy. Weed, syrup, pills, and who knows what else are his muses, and this year he’s found a woozy place where life seems perpetually submerged in a Styrofoam cup. The slow-mo re-work of Zan With That Lean gives you the full double-cup treatment, but it’s on the original where Soulja finds bliss in pure pop.

songs.full_title: Draco by Soulja Boy (Ft. Famous Dex)
songs.title: Draco

description.plain:
Century Arms' Draco Pistol is patterned after the AK-47 assault rifle, and uses the same ammunition. Draco is latin for dragon. The gun’s muzzle flash is similar to the way a dragon breathes fire, an effect which is especially dramatic when firing 7.62x39mm assault rifle rounds from a pistol.



Since being enshrined in rap history as the subject of Soulja Boy’s song, the weapon has been mentioned frequently by rappers such as Future, Migos, SahBabii and 21 Savage.

songs.full_title: Goku by Soulja Boy
songs.title: Goku

description.plain:
Goku means “sky” in Japanese – perhaps Soulja Boy means to say that he’s high..

It’s also the name of the hero in the Dragonball cartoons. In the video above (which we hope is fake) Soulja boy is actually Gohan, for some reasons we cannot fathom Tupac is Goku. Biggie also takes a role-as King Kai.

songs.full_title: Yahhh! by Soulja Boy (Ft. Arab SODMG)
songs.title: Yahhh!

description.plain:
Third single off of SouljaBoyTellem.com.  It received extremely negative reviews from critics. DigitalSpy said of the song:

Based around Soulja and pal Arab screaming incomprehensible gibberish, the repeated line “Yahhh, Trick, Yahhh!” is more irritating than a life’s supply or itching powder, while the bargain bucket synth soundtrack sounds like an old Nokia ringtone.

songs.full_title: Grammy by Soulja Boy (Ft. Ester Dean)
songs.title: Grammy

description.plain: In a rather emotional conclusion to this album Soulja, brings this narrative back to the present time. He reflects on his previous albums in demonstration that he is aware he messed up. He pledged his soul to the industry instead of his strong and prevailing fanbase. To conclude the album, Soulja powerfully asserts to the Music Industry that if they cannot appreciate his most honest and introspective work yet and reward him with a Grammy, he does not desire to ever win one. Throughout this entire album, Soulja recognizes his failures in standing up to the Industry and finally demonstrates himself as in individualistic artist who does not work for the Industry, but for the people. This powerful conclusion captivates the resounding themes of this album thematically.

songs.full_title: First Day of School by Soulja Boy
songs.title: First Day of School

description.plain:
This is the opening track on Soulja’s The DeAndre Way. In this song Soulja Boy comments on the superficiality of the hip-hop world, and his melancholy delivery gives the listener the impression that he’s tired of the culture that he’s had a part in creating. “Hat goin' match my shirt./ Shirt goin' match my belt.” While me may look fresh to def, Soulja doesn’t care anymore. he wants more substance in his life.
One could also argue that with this song Soulja Boy is expressing his regret for dropping out of high school to pursue his music career. “I bet I dress every day like it’s the first day of school.” Soulja has forgotten what it means to go to school for the first time since he’s so far gone.

description.plain:
“Passing” in this context (knowing Soulja Boy) would give us the preimpression that this would be drugs, presumably a blunt of Marijuana.

After listening, we interpret that he is giving Arab a chance with the microphone, since Soulja is generally the one to shine. (you know, 25 million dollar net worth and all)

songs.full_title: Report Card by Soulja Boy (Ft. Arab SODMG)
songs.title: Report Card

description.plain:
This song is a parody of “Throw Some D’s” by Rich Boy. In that song, “Throw some D’s on it” means putting expensive Dayton Rims (“D’s”) on a Cadillac. This song is about Soulja Boy and Arab demanding that a teacher give them mediocre-but-passing grades on their report cards in courses they failed.

Although the beat used is different, this song samples the “Throw some D’s on it” line directly from the original Rich Boy song.

songs.full_title: Kim Kardashian by Soulja Boy
songs.title: Kim Kardashian

description.plain:
Continuing Soulja Boy’s quest to push his lyrical ambiguity to new extremes, “Kim Kardashian” might be an insightful critique of our culture’s obsession with image and glamour – but the lyrics are ripe with other possibilities. Perhaps the song is an open-minded examination of the positive impact Kim Kardashian has had on our culture? Or maybe it’s an inside look at the divide between Kim’s public image and her real personality? I don’t know, but all I can say is, that verse where he rhymes “swag” with “swag” sure is hot!

ps does Lil B get a writing credit on this? His based fingerprints are all over it….
